title: Creates the New York Stem Cell Research Institute
summary: Creates the New York Stem Cell Research Institute; provides for the appointment of the New York state stem cell board, to be composed of nineteen members, to run the institute; establishes the powers, duties, procedures, and functions of the institute.

                                   I N  S E N A T E

       Introduced  by  Sens. PERKINS, DUANE, HASSELL-THOMPSON, STAVISKY -- read

       AN ACT creating the New York Stem Cell Research Institute

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Short title. This act shall be known and may  be  cited  as
    2  the "New York Stem Cell Research Institute act".
    3    S  2.  Legislative intent. Millions of children and adults suffer from
    4  devastating diseases or injuries that are currently incurable, including
    5  cancer, diabetes, heart disease, Parkinson's disease, spinal cord  inju-
    6  ries,  blindness,  Lou  Gehrig's disease, HIV/AIDS, mental health disor-
    7  ders, multiple sclerosis, Huntington's disease, and  more  than  seventy
    8  other diseases and injuries.
    9    Recently,  medical  science has discovered a new way to attack chronic
   10  diseases and injuries. The cure and  treatment  of  these  diseases  can
   11  potentially  be accomplished through the use of new regenerative medical
   12  therapies including a special type of human cells,  called  stem  cells.
   13  These  life-saving  medical  breakthroughs  can  only happen if adequate
   14  funding is made available to advance stem cell research, develop  thera-
   15  pies, and conduct clinical trials.
   16    Unfortunately,  the  federal  government is not providing the adequate
   17  funding necessary for the  urgent  research  and  facilities  needed  to
   18  develop stem cell therapies to treat and cure diseases and serious inju-
   19  ries. This critical funding gap currently prevents the rapid advancement
   20  of research that could benefit millions of New Yorkers.
   21    S 3. New York Stem Cell Research Institute. a. There is hereby created
   22  an  institute  to be known as the New York Stem Cell Research Institute,
   23  which shall have the following purposes:
   24    (1) To make grants and loans for  stem  cell  research,  for  research
   25  facilities, and for other vital research opportunities to realize thera-

    1  pies,  protocols,  and/or  medical  procedures  that  will result in, as
    2  speedily as possible, the cure for, and/or  substantial  mitigation  of,
    3  major diseases, injuries, and orphan diseases.
    4    (2)  To  support  all  stages of the process of developing cures, from
    5  laboratory research through successful clinical trials.
    6    (3) To establish appropriate regulatory standards and oversight bodies
    7  for research and facilities development.
    8    b. No fund authorized for, or made available to, the  institute  shall
    9  be used for research involving human reproductive cloning.
   10    c.  Funds authorized for, or made available to, the institute shall be
   11  continuously appropriated without regard to fiscal  year,  be  available
   12  and  used  only  for the purposes provided in this act, and shall not be
   13  subject to appropriation or transfer by the legislature or the  governor
   14  for any other purpose.
   15    S  4.  There  shall  be  established within the institute the New York
   16  state stem cell board, hereinafter, the board, which  shall  govern  the
   17  institute and is hereby vested with full power, authority, and jurisdic-
   18  tion over the institute.
   19    S  5.  The  New  York  state  stem  cell  board. a. The board shall be
   20  composed of nineteen members, who shall be appointed  in  the  following
   21  manner:  five  shall  be  appointed  by  the  governor;  three  shall be
   22  appointed by the temporary president of the senate; two by the  minority
   23  leader  of  the  senate;  three shall be appointed by the speaker of the
   24  assembly; two by the minority leader of the assembly; two by  the  state
   25  comptroller;  and two by the attorney general.  The members of the board
   26  shall be representative  of  the  public,  not-for-profit  academic  and
   27  research  institutions,  life  science  commercial entities, and disease
   28  advocacy groups.
   29    b. All appointments shall be made within forty days of  the  effective
   30  date  of  this  act.  In  the event that any of the appointments are not
   31  completed within the permitted time frame, the board  shall  proceed  to
   32  operate  with the appointments that are in place, provided that at least
   33  sixty percent of the appointments have been made.
   34    c. Board members shall serve six-year terms.  Members  shall  serve  a
   35  maximum  of two terms. If a vacancy occurs within a term, the appointing
   36  authority shall serve a maximum of two terms. If a vacancy occurs within
   37  a term, the appointing authority  shall  appoint  a  replacement  member
   38  within  thirty  days  to  serve  the  remainder of the term. When a term
   39  expires, the appointing authority shall appoint a member  within  thirty
   40  days. The board members shall continue to serve until their replacements
   41  are appointed.
   42    S  6.  The  board  shall  have the following powers and duties: a. The
   43  board shall elect a chairperson and vice chairperson within  forty  days
   44  of  the  effective  date  of this act. Each constitutional officer shall
   45  nominate a candidate for chairperson  and  another  candidate  for  vice
   46  chairperson.  The chairperson and vice chairperson shall each be elected
   47  for  a  term  of  six years. The chairperson and vice chairperson of the
   48  board shall be full or part time employees of the  institute  and  shall
   49  meet the following criteria:
   50    (1) have a documented history in successful stem cell research advoca-
   51  cy;
   52    (2)  have experience with state and federal legislative processes that
   53  must include some experience with medical legislative approvals of stan-
   54  dards and/or funding;
   55    (3) are not concurrently employed by or on leave from any  prospective
   56  grant or loan recipient institutions in New York;

       S. 2784                             3

    1    (4) have experience with governmental agencies or institutions, either
    2  executive or board position;
    3    (5)  have  experience  with  the  process of establishing governmental
    4  standards and procedures;
    5    (6) have legal experience with the legal review of proper governmental
    6  authority for the exercise of government agency or  government  institu-
    7  tional powers;
    8    (7) have direct knowledge and experience in bond financing.
    9    b.  Actions  of  the  board  may be taken only by a majority vote of a
   10  quorum of the board.
   11    c. The board shall oversee the operations of the institute.
   12    d. The board shall develop annual and long-term strategic research and
   13  financial plans for the institute.
   14    e. The board shall make final  decisions  on  research  standards  and
   15  grant awards in New York.
   16    f.  Ensure  the  completion of an annual financial audit of the insti-
   17  tute's operations.
   18    g. Issue public reports on the activities of the institute.
   19    h. Establish policies regarding intellectual property  rights  arising
   20  from research funded by the institute.
   21    i.  Establish  rules and guidelines for the operation of the board and
   22  its working groups.
   23    j. Perform all other acts necessary or appropriate in the exercise  of
   24  its power, authority, and jurisdiction over the institute.
   25    k.  Adopt,  amend,  and rescind rules and regulations to carry out the
   26  purposes and provisions of this act, and to govern the procedures of the
   27  board. These rules and regulations shall be adopted in  accordance  with
   28  the state administrative procedure act.
   29    S  7.  Public and financial accountability standards. a. Annual public
   30  report. The institute shall issue an annual report to the public,  which
   31  sets  forth its activities, grants awarded, grants in progress, research
   32  accomplishments, and future program  directions.    Each  annual  report
   33  shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
   34    (1) the number and dollar amounts of research and facilities grants;
   35    (2) the grantees for the prior year;
   36    (3) the institute's administrative expenses;
   37    (4)  an  assessment  of  the  availability  of  funding  for stem cell
   38  research from sources other than the institute;
   39    (5) a summary of research findings, including promising  new  research
   40  areas;
   41    (6)  an  assessment of the relationship between the institute's grants
   42  and the overall strategy of its research program;
   43    (7) a report of  the  institute's  strategic  research  and  financial
   44  plans.
   45    b.  Independent  financial  audit for review by state comptroller. The
   46  institute shall annually commission an independent  financial  audit  of
   47  its  activities  from a certified public accounting firm, which shall be
   48  provided to the state comptroller, who shall review the audit and  annu-
   49  ally issue a public report of that review.
   50    c. Citizen's financial accountability oversight committee. There shall
   51  be  a  citizen's financial accountability oversight committee chaired by
   52  the state comptroller. This committee shall review the annual  financial
   53  audit,  the state comptroller's report and evaluation of that audit, and
   54  the financial practices of the institute.  The  state  comptroller,  the
   55  state  treasurer,  the temporary president of the senate, the speaker of
   56  the assembly, and the chairperson of the  board  shall  each  appoint  a

       S. 2784                             4

    1  public  member  of  the  committee. Committee members shall have medical
    2  backgrounds and knowledge of relevant financial matters.  The  committee
    3  shall  provide recommendations on the institute's financial practice and
    4  performance.    The  state  comptroller shall provide staff support. The
    5  committee shall hold a public meeting, with appropriate notice, and with
    6  a formal public comment period.  The  committee  shall  evaluate  public
    7  comments  and  include  appropriate  summaries in its annual report. The
    8  board shall provide funds for the per diem  expenses  of  the  committee
    9  members and for publication of the annual report.
   10    S  8.  Conflicts  of  interest.  a. No member of the board shall make,
   11  participate in making, or in any way attempt to use his or her  official
   12  position  to  influence a decision to approve or award a grant, loan, or
   13  contract to his or her employer, but a member may participate in a deci-
   14  sion to approve or award a grant, loan, or contract to a nonprofit enti-
   15  ty in the same field as his or her employer.
   16    b. A member of the board may participate in a decision to  approve  or
   17  award  a  grant,  loan,  or  contract  to  an  entity for the purpose of
   18  research involving a disease from which a member or his or her immediate
   19  family suffers or in which the member has an  interest  as  a  represen-
   20  tative of a disease advocacy organization.
   21    c.  The  adoption  of  standards  is  not  a  decision subject to this
   22  section.
   23    d. Service as a member of the board by a  member  of  the  faculty  or
   24  administration  of  any  system  of  the  state university shall not, by
   25  itself, be deemed to be inconsistent, incompatible, in conflict with, or
   26  inimical to the duties of the board member as a member of the faculty or
   27  administration of any system of  the  state  university  and  shall  not
   28  result in the automatic vacation of either such office.
   29    e. Service as a member of the board by a representative or employee of
   30  a  disease  advocacy  organization,  a  nonprofit  academic and research
   31  institution, or a life science commercial entity shall not be deemed  to
   32  be  inconsistent,  incompatible,  in  conflict  with, or inimical to the
   33  duties of the board member as  a  representative  or  employee  of  that
   34  organization, institution, or entity.
   35    S  9. Patent royalties and license revenues. The board shall establish
   36  standards that require that all grants and loan  awards  be  subject  to
   37  intellectual  property  agreements  that  balance the opportunity of the
   38  state of New York to benefit from the patents, royalties,  and  licenses
   39  that  result  from  basic  research,  therapy  development, and clinical
   40  trials with the need to assure that essential medical  research  is  not
   41  unreasonably hindered by the intellectual property agreements.
   42    S  10.  Preference  for  New York suppliers. The board shall establish
   43  standards to ensure that grantees purchase goods and services  from  New
   44  York suppliers to the extent reasonably possible, in a good faith effort
   45  to  achieve a goal of more than fifty percent of such purchases from New
   46  York suppliers.
   47    S 11. This act shall take effect immediately.
